metadata.sermon_start_end: The pastor of the old Fort Street Presbyterian Church in Detroit was driving me to his city's airport. He had been preaching on the parables of Jesus. Suddenly he put the question bluntly to me, 'Where do you think Jesus got all of those stories?' [...] Above his omnipresence, his equal attendance everywhere at the same time, 'he first loved us.' Above his omnipotence, his power without limitation, 'he first loved us.'

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker's first requirement. It is a topical speech about 'love' rather than an exposition of a specific pericope. It jumps between various biblical references (Matthew, Luke, Exodus, 1 John, Revelation) to support a general theme. The 'NOWHERE else' principle is ignored; the preacher treats the Bible as a reservoir of 'likes' and 'similarities' rather than a specific word for a specific moment.
quotes: Thus, all through the Scriptures God's relationship to us is set forth in likes...
Love in all its forms is used in the Bible to illustrate God's interest in us...
Read my text in the Revised Standard Version of the Bible and it leaves off 'him'...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one specific pericope (e.g., 1 John 4:7-21) and stay within its unique logic instead of using it as a springboard for a general discourse on the concept of love.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is superficial and subordinated to the thematic goal. While the preacher mentions Greek terms (eros, philia, agape), this is done in a textbook fashion rather than as an exploration of the text's original historical or theological context. The 'original readers' are never addressed.
quotes: For that the Greeks had a word, eros...
The great New Testament word for love is neither eros... nor philia... but agape.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond word studies. Investigate the specific polemical or pastoral situation of the Johannine community to understand why this specific word was spoken then.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is broad but often slips into generalities. While it mentions specific locations (Africa, Italy, Atlanta, New York) and political issues (black community empowerment), these feel like a list of contemporary 'topics' rather than a direct, inevitable consequence of the specific text's exposition.
quotes: Where people are hungry in Africa and homeless in Italy and families mourn and a city lies in fear near Atlanta...
Protest meetings are good, but people are not put in office by protest meetings...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the political and social application more strictly to the theological 'why' of the text, rather than offering general civic advice on voting.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured as a series of reflections and anecdotes. Exposition and application are not 'mixed' in a movement that 'expounds' the hearer; rather, the sermon moves from abstract definitions of love to various illustrations and finally to a list of applications.
quotes: The great New Testament word for love is... agape. It is what we meet in our text.
And we can show that love for God by the care we give...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Use the text to analyze the hearer's current reality immediately, rather than defining terms first and applying them later.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The three parts are present in the background. Misery is addressed through the lens of unworthiness and 'ugly thoughts.' Redemption is clearly Christocentric (Calvary). Gratitude is framed as 'turning back some faint reflection.' However, the 'misery' feels somewhat moralistic ('biggest liar in Brooklyn') rather than ontological.
quotes: He first loved you, first loved me in all of my unworthiness, in all of our rebelliousness and selfishness.
I would have to brand you as the biggest liar in Brooklyn.
We love because God first loved us.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect by showing how man is lost without this specific word, moving beyond mere 'ugly thoughts' to the radical need for grace.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are almost entirely absent. The sermon emphasizes a universal 'Greatest Love Affair' where God's love is 'the central theme of the universe.' The seriousness of being lost (temporal or eternal) is softened by the overwhelming emphasis on a love that is 'central' even in 'ten billion light years' of space.
quotes: This is our ground for believing that this universe is keyed to love.
That is the central theme of the universe, that is the central theme of life.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Incorporate the Johannine tension: love is a command and a crisis (krisis). Address the possibility of refusing this love and the consequence of that refusal.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: This is the sermon's strongest point. Christ is clearly the telos. The preacher emphasizes that grace is unmerited and that Christ's work on Calvary is the definitive proof of God's love. The doctrine of the two natures is implicit in the 'Fairer than ten thousand' section.
quotes: A fairer one than any village lad threw himself into death's awful waters for you and for me.
Christ died for you and me.
He loved me and gave himself for me.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is not just a 'theme' or an 'illustration' of love, but the actual presence of God acting for us.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 2150 words, the sermon meets Dekker's requirement for 'breadth.' It allows time for anecdotes and theological reflection, though the 'depth' is compromised by the topical nature of the content.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Use the available time to dig deeper into one text rather than covering many disparate biblical and personal anecdotes.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's ideal primarily because it is a topical speech on the theme of 'love' rather than an exposition of a specific Bible passage. It lacks the 'two ways' tension, leaning toward a sentimental universalism where love is the 'theme of the universe.' While it is Christocentric and sufficiently long, it relies too heavily on anecdotes and general truths rather than the specific, unique word of a single pericope.
strengths: Christocentric focus: The sermon consistently points to Christ's sacrifice as the source of grace.
Adequate length: The preacher takes the time to develop thoughts, avoiding the 'short speech' trap.
Concrete social application: The mention of political empowerment in Brooklyn provides a necessary, though loosely connected, earthly anchor.
weaknesses: Lack of specific pericope: The sermon treats the Bible as a collection of proof-texts for a general theme.
Absence of the 'Two Ways': There is no sense of the urgency of choice or the reality of being lost.
Over-reliance on anecdote: The long introductory story and personal reminiscences occupy space that should be reserved for textual exposition.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: According to Dekker's criteria, this is not a 'rightly proclaimed' sermon but a thematic speech. It fails the formal definition of 'exposition and application of a specific Bible passage.' It is an eloquent discourse on a biblical idea, but it lacks the specificity and the 'crisis' of the Word that Dekker demands.
